question_title: Will the Bank of Japan raise its policy interest rate again before May 1, 2026?
summary: The BOJ is at 0.75% after its December 2025 hike and held steady in January 2026. Two meetings fall in the resolution window: March (~mid-March) and April 27-28. The analyst consensus (Reuters poll) is that the next hike comes in July 2026, with >75% expecting rates at 1%+ by September. However, BOJ insiders have leaked that April is "a distinct possibility," board member Takata dissented in January wanting to hike to 1%, and spring wage data (shunto) plus the April 1 Tankan survey will be available by the April meeting. Counterbalancing this: PM Takaichi is a fiscal dove who may pressure BOJ to delay, a February snap election adds political uncertainty, and market pricing (OIS) suggests less than one full hike within 12 months. The April 27-28 meeting is the most likely candidate for a hike within the window, but it remains a minority probability scenario.

factors.description: Reuters poll: >75% of analysts expect next BOJ hike in July or later, making April minority view
BOJ insiders leaked to Reuters that April is 'a distinct possibility' - trial balloon signal
Board member Takata dissented in January wanting to hike to 1% - showing internal hawkish pressure
Spring wage negotiations (shunto) expected to deliver ~5% raises, supporting BOJ case for hikes by April
BOJ raised its own growth and inflation forecasts in January, signaling confidence in normalization path
PM Takaichi is fiscal dove/reflationist who has challenged BOJ independence - may pressure BOJ to delay
February snap election creates short-term political uncertainty for BOJ action
1-year OIS at 0.84% (vs 0.75% rate) suggests market prices less than one full 25bp hike in 12 months
BOJ is in active tightening cycle with pattern of hikes every 4-11 months; April would be ~5 months from Dec
Nothing Ever Happens adjustment: analyst consensus is later, and April would be a surprise to many
